description:
Taphrina deformans PYCC 5710 is a species of ascomycete fungus that belongs to the genus Taphrina. It is the causative agent of peach leaf curl, a common disease affecting peach (Prunus persica) and nectarine trees.

The fungus is characterized by its ability to infect the leaves, flowers, and young fruits of the host plant, leading to characteristic deformations and distortions. Taphrina deformans PYCC 5710 is an obligate parasite, meaning it can only grow and reproduce on living host plants.

The life cycle of Taphrina deformans PYCC 5710 involves the formation of asci, which are sac-like structures that contain haploid ascospores. These ascospores are released and can infect the host plant, leading to the development of the characteristic leaf curl symptoms.

Taphrina deformans PYCC 5710 is an important pathogen in agricultural settings, as it can significantly reduce the yield and quality of peach and nectarine crops if left uncontrolled. Understanding the biology and ecology of this fungus is crucial for the development of effective management strategies to mitigate the impact of peach leaf curl disease.
